Ok, so this game has a few flaw, but overall it is an enjoyable experience. I myself am a huge fan of the shmup genre, with Starfox (the original for SNES, not 64) being the first game I ever played to completion, and this game definitely deserves a spot on the shelf with other shmups. Let's get right into it, shall we?  Pros:  - MUSIC! This game has some of the most up-beat, driving, and overall motivating music I've heard in an indie shmup for a while  - Variation: This game doesn't just ask you to shoot everything. It requires you to master all forms of gameplay presented.   - Well paced. This game doesn't have a difficulty wall. It gradually eases you into the harder and harder levels. And even as the levels progress, it is preparing you for what's to come.  Cons:  - Control... No matter your ship, you control like you're flying a blimp  - Graphics: The graphics are lacking a bit. I gather that this is an indie game, but everything looks a bit too flat and uninspired. There's no real art direction other than 'Standard space shmup.'  I rather enjoy this game and can see myself playing it quite a bit in the future. That said, it's not the best game I've ever played. There is certainly better, but for $2, I'm not going to complain.

Poor, even for the 24c it cost me.  The graphics are dated, the aesthetic is generic, the level designs on the early levels are incredibly boring, the enemies just fade in and stick in one spot, the sound FX aren't anything special, the ship is set way too close to the camera, the controls feel unresponsive, the settings menu requires you to exit the game to apply graphics settings (really?), etc.  If you absolutely adore tunnel/rail shooters, I could see maybe being amused by it for a short period of time, however, I think there are much more interesting/better games in this genre. It feels like a mobile game in the worst ways.
